loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital

location.town: Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Medarda

texts.en:
Medarda H. lives in Nangka, Das Village, Toledo City, Cebu. She is married and has eight children, four of whom attend school and three of whom are presently working.  She earns her living by operating two business ventures: furniture making and ready-to-wear clothes businesses. Her husband, Rolando H., who is 50 years old, works in the furniture business to earn his living.  He also helps in his wife's business activities.  Medarda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Medarda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 30,000 PHP, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  For her 11th  loan, she is borrowing 20,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy lumber for her furniture business so that she could continue to save up for the future and for her children's education.  Medarda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Nargis' Group

texts.en:
Nargis lives in Lahore, the second largest city of Pakistan known for its history and culture. She lives in the Shalimar area with her family in a two-room brick house. She came here 10 years ago.

Her husband’s name is M. H. and he is a blacksmith by profession. He provides iron rods to his customers and earns income for the family. His shop is in the market and he is known for his expertise in his field.

Nargis is a talented lady and operates a business making shoes. She receives orders from local shoe factories and fulfills their orders on time to support her family financially. She has given birth to a son who is a driver by profession and drives a rickshaw, providing transport services to his customers. He has completed his 10th grade and is 22 years old.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy iron to help him to make iron rods in larger quantities to fulfill his customers orders and earn good income. Nargis is hopeful that a loan investment will be a profitable one for her husband and bring positive changes to his business.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Nargis.

loans.use: To buy iron for iron rod making business.

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea O. is from the town of Surallah. She is 54 years old, married, and has three children. To make a living, Irenea raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Irenea works hard to provide for the increasing needs in her household. She hopes to have a stable income.

Irenea joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irenea has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.  Irenea is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Morita

texts.en:
Morita G. is 57 years old, married, and has one child. She lives in Coastal Place of Jala-jala, Rizal, Philippines. She and her husband work hard to offer their family a better life.  They decided to join ASHI in 2000 to acquire capital for their business, which is fishing. They have requested a new loan of  20,000 PHP, which they will use to buy more fishnet, rope, bamboo, and fingerlings (small fish). Morita hopes to build a beautiful house, expand her fishing business, and have more space for their fishing equipment. 

The family feels very happy with the loan because it improved their lives. Morita wishes all lenders all the best and good luck and will continue to support ASHI, which helps poor families like them, who want to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fishnet, rope, bamboo, and fingerlings

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a taxi driver from Khan Younis city in Gaza Strip. Ibrahim bought a taxi car 5 years ago and has been using it since then. Ibrahim gave the owner of the car a down payment from his savings and started paying the rest of the cost on a monthly basis from his work returns.

Now that Ibrahim has only one payment left, he came to FATEN and took a loan to pay it and fully own the car. The car is two families' source of income as Ibrahim and his son Muhammad (who appears in the picture here because Ibrahim is a conservative man and doesn't want to be in the picture) share use of the car.  The son is married and has his own family.

About this loan product:
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m

loans.use: To pay the last payment on a taxi car

loans.name: Rahat's Group

texts.en:
Rahat is a caring lady who lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan and known for its history and culture. In order to support her family financially, she does embroidery work at her home, receiving orders from her neighborhood clients.

Her husband’s name is M. T. and he operates a milk shop in the market. He has contacts with different milk providers in the nearby village. They provide him milk and he stores it in the fridge and freezer to maintain its freshness. He also makes yogurt and sells it for a good profit.

Rahat is the mother of three sons, all of whom are illiterate as they couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints. Her eldest son works with his father at his shop. Her second son works as a salesman and the youngest works in bus repair workshop.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband in his business. With the loan, he will buy a new fridge because his current fridge has become out of order. The new fridge will help him provide fresh quality milk and yogurt to his customers. Rahat’s husband has been doing this business for over 17 years and she is hopeful that by utilizing the loan, her husband will successfully be able to improve his business condition. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has established a good credit record and attended every meeting.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Rahat.

loans.use: To buy a new fridge for a milk shop.

loans.name: Herdenia

texts.en:
Herdenia A. is from Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Herdenia is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Herdenia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from dealing in cosmetics, lotions & deodorant products from NATASHA & AVON  in the local community. Herdenia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Herdenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Herdenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Herdenia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Herdenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en:
Gantumur B. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Gantumur operates a  retail dairy business in his town, together with his wife. 

Gantumur purchases his dairy products from Zuunbayanulaan and Batulzii sub-provinces and sells them at the central market in main town of the province or in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He sells a variety of dairy products wholesale to the dairy products traders in his local town and through his sibling who owns a stall in the market in Ulaanbaatar. 

Since beginning his business, he has been able not only to provide for his family, but he has also been able to purchase a plot of land and a fence where he has built a house. Gantumur hopes to continue to grow his business so that he can provide for his family in the future. He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more dairy products at wholesale prices and preserve them in order to sell them when prices for such products rise.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
This is Leticia Q., 53, a widow who raised her four working children and one elementary child in GMA, Cavite, Philippines.  With the help of her four working children, she works hard daily to earn a living and able to send her youngest child even up to college.

At present, Leticia focuses on running her sari-sari (variety) store. She aims to meet the daily needs of her neighborhood in soft drinks and grocery items such as shampoo, and also canned goods, and seasonings, among others. With this business, Leticia earns an average of Php 300 a day.

Leticia knows inside her that the sari-sari store will not be enough to meet the needs and wants of her family. To help her continue operation of her variety store, she would like to apply for a Php 25,000 loan. She plans to use this money to add more items to her store and keep the small business in shape. In just a small period of time, she intends to turn her small sari-sari store into a real grocery store, with more items to meet the needs of people in her community.

All that Leticia dreams of in life is to make her family happy and give them a house they can call their own. She gives her best to make sure her youngest child gets a good education up through college. Life is not always sweet, but with all the efforts she is making for her family, she sees to it that she will emerge a winner, bringing home sweet success.  Leticia faithfully attends weekly fellowship* meetings. 


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: additional stock for variety store

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She lives in the area named Shalimar with her family in a two-room brick house. She came here after her marriage.

Her husband’s name is M. W. and he is a motor mechanic who runs a motor workshop. He has 12 years of experience in his work and has a good technical knowledge of his business. He can repair every kind of vehicle and people approach him and trust him for his good and quality work.

Nusrat is a very supportive lady and supports her family financially by making artificial jewelry. She receives orders from different jewelry shops and makes jewelry on order to earn an income for the family. She also has a part-time business selling clothes to her neighboring clients. She has four daughters and a son. All of her children are very young and getting their education, except for the youngest who is four years old.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his business. He will invest the loan in purchasing the latest repair tools for his motor workshop to provide better quality services to his clients and finish repairing orders on time. Nusrat is hopeful that a loan investment will make her husband’s business more profitable and help her family achieve a better standard of living.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and attended every meeting.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Nusrat.

loans.use: To buy the latest repair tools for a motor workshop business.

loans.name: Ronda

texts.en:
Ronda, from the village of Tinacla-an, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, is 49 years old and single. She owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for sale. Ronda has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years, earning approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Ronda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future, Ronda is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her eighth loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her agricultural business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is married and in business. She is a mother to 4 children who are in school. She operates a garage and also offers welding services in Machakos. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kes to buy metal sheets and welding bits for her welding business. She employs two people and hopes to own an industry in future. Since joining Faulu, her living standard has improved and she has been able to educate all her children. She describes herself as focused and active. (Note: Photo was taken away from her business.)

loans.use: To buy metal sheets and welding bits

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan M. is a 32-year-old and lives with her husband and three children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family lives together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in her sister's yard, in one of the 'ger' districts on the outskirts of the city. Her older two children both attend a primary school and Bayasgalan operates a clothing-making business. 

She makes a variety of clothes and sells them in Narantuul, the largest and most important market in the city. She began her business in 2004 and has since gained significant experience. After several years of hard work and determination, her working capital now exceeds 1,500,000 MNT with cash balance of 450,000 MNT. Her hope is to keep growing her business so that she can afford to pay her children’s tuition fees. 

Bayasgalan is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase two new, more efficient sewing machines at 500,000 MNT and more clothing fabric at 800,000 MNT for her growing business.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina lives in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. She lives in a two-room brick house with her family in the area named Shalimar. Her husband is 58 and no longer works due to his age. He prefers to stay at home.

Robina is a very active lady. She offers her services of sewing clothes to her neighboring clients to fulfill the needs of the family. She has four sons who have left their education and started working to financially support their family. Two of her four sons are married. All sons are involved in the same business of making sofa covers and have shops in the market.

Robina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan, he will buy large quantities of cloth and foam to fulfill larger orders of making sofa covers orders on time. He started this business 15 years ago and Robina is hopeful that by utilizing the loan money, her son will be able to improve the financial condition of the family. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she built good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Robina.

loans.use: To buy cloth and foam for her business making sofa covers.

loans.name: Byambahuu

texts.en:
Byambahuu T. is 54 years old and lives with her husband and and daughter in their own house and fence in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her older two children both live on their own while her youngest daughter attends university. 

Byambahuu sells women’s handbags in the largest Ulaanbaatar market, Narantuul. She began her business in 1995 and since has built a stable and successful operation. Most of her siblings and relatives have also operated a variety of bag-selling business. She purchases bags from China. 

Today her working capital is 2,500,000 MNT and her daily average sales income is between 50,000 and 80,000 MNT. Byambahuu is a clever and hard-working businesswoman and says, " Now I am planning to buy a car for my daughter." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more quality and well designed leather handbags from Beijing, the capital city of China.

loans.use: To purchase more good quality and well designed leather handbags

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie B. is from the village of Malinao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 49 years old. Rosie is separated from her spouse and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Rosie owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling green and sweet bananas, and also selling junk foods & canned goods, retailing charcoal per kilogram & fruit such as mangoes & guavas in the local community. Rosie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Rosie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel J. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. He is 34 years old. Manuel is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Manuel owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing "motorela" or "habal-habal" services to local community members. Manuel has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Manuel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Manuel is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed to expand services provided. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Manuel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Erhembileg

texts.en:
Erhembileg D. is 48 years old and lives with her mother, her siblings and her son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of  Mongolia. She and her family live in their own apartment. Her sibling is a mini-bus driver and operates a transportation service within the city using her micro bus, which was purchased with a loan from XacBank. She and her sibling have hired two more employees for the transportation business. 

Erhembileg has been operating a shoe trade business in the Narantuul trade market in the city since 2002. She provides a variety of shoes to satisfy her customers' needs and owns a stall in the market where she sells the products. After some years of positive growth with her business, she has built a stable operation and her working capital has reached a level of 2000000 MNT. She is a very clever and open-minded person and says, " My son will start attending university by next year. Therefore I need to prepare for it." 

She is requesting a 2500000 MNT loan to import winter shoes from Erlian, a border city of China, to sell.

loans.use: To import winter shoes

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa J., 53, lost her dear partner in life, but now lives for her one child, who is in college. Elsa and her child currently stay in Caloocan City, Philippines. With all heart and strength, Elsa strives to make sure she gives her child a good life.

Elsa manages a computer shop, which is up and growing a year after it was started. Elsa offers Internet access to people in her community, particularly to the young generation who use the Web for educational purposes as well as for entertainment. Adults also gain needed Internet access, thanks to Elsa's business, which earns PHP 400 on an average day.

Elsa plans to add one more computer to her store in order to accommodate more customers, so she would like to apply  to CCT* for a PHP 18000 loan. Her ultimate goal for her business is to increase the number of her computers and expand the business.

At present, Elsa battles the lack of sleep brought by having to supervise the computer shop from early morning to late at night. But if her goal of attaining a happy, abundant life with her only child is to be kept in mind, Elsa is sure to win the battle and live life to its fullest.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase an additional computer for her Internet services business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia K. M. is married and the mother of two children who go to school. 

She has been in the cereals and fruits business for the last three years. She is requesting for a loan of 30000 KES to buy maize, beans, fruits and other food items. 

Since joining Faulu Kenya, she has managed to educate her children. She describes herself as focused and hardworking and hopes to have a well established business in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize, beans, fruits and other food items

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth F. is from the village of Canituan, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Maribeth is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Maribeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, breads and instant noodles in the local community. Maribeth has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Maribeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Maribeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maribeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the seventh loan taken by Maribeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Myagmarhajid

texts.en:
Myagmarhajid Y. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family sold their house and fence and purchased their own apartment, where they live,  with a leasing loan. 

Both her two children attend university and her husband is a driver in the factory. 

Myagmarhajid operates a women's lingerie retail business from a stall at the main market in Narantuul. She sells a variety of different women's underwear and lingerie and her wide product selection attracts many customers. She started her business in 2000 and since has built a stable operation. After many years of running this business, she has gained a lot of experience as a trader. Today, her working capital exceeds 1500000 MNT. 

Both of her siblings also operate women's underwear-selling businesses out of different stalls. She is a clever, honest and open-minded person. She is requesting a 1000000 MNT loan to import more women's underwear and lingerie from Erlian, a border city of China.

loans.use: To import more women's underwear and lingerie

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria T. is from the town of Surallah. She is 50 years old. To make a living, Maria raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Maria also makes bukayo, a dessert made from young coconut. She travels around her neighborhood selling bukayo.

Maria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Maria is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and bukayo ingredients. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and bukayo ingredients

loans.name: Tutu's Group

texts.en:
Tutu A. is the leader of this group. She is 57 years old, married, and has one child who works in construction.  Her husband is a pensioner.  Seven years ago with the initial investment of 500 soms Tutu started to sell convenience goods near her house. She now earns 8,000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to save money to start building her own store.  With money received from the loan Tutu wants to purchase convenience goods such as rice, oil, and macaroni in order to increase the inventory of her business. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods for sale

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is a married woman with one child who has graduated from school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity, but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For more than 14 years, she has operated a secondhand clothing sales business, selling at the market to town residents, neighbors and passersby. Aziza faces a major challenge of high cost of transporting clothes to the marketplace. She hopes to establish a boutique in the future. 

She decided to join Yehu to get loans to boost her business. With the loan of Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase a bale of clothes.

loans.use: To  purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Oyunbat

texts.en:
Oyunbat N. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. Both of her daughters are university students, while her husband operates a transportation service to support their family. 

Oyunbat operates a small grocery store in her town. She sells a variety food and consumer products at her grocery store. She started her grocery business in 2000,  and has since been successful enough to expand her food retail business into a grocery shop. After many years of owning this business, she has built a stable and successful operation. Her shop is located in a popular spot in her area, which attracts many customers. Her business' earnings have created financial stability for her family. 

Oyunbat is a very hardworking businesswoman and is known for her good character. She says, "All I want is to enlarge my business and establish my own comfortable supermarket in the future"  She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase grocery products to sell at her shop.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for resale

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine Hitayezu is 32 years old and married to a veteran. She has four children between the ages of 1 and 12 years old. Three of her children go to school. Francine sells fruit, such as oranges; she has had this business for the period of ten years. 

She has requested this loan to buy more fruit to sell. She would also like to buy some livestock, which could provide much return in the future. Her business has done much for her daily life.  She dreams of owning a truck, which may help her in the transportation of her fruit and enable her to become a supplier in the future.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to resell

loans.name: Jowasi

texts.en:
Jowasi is 27 years old and married to a farmer. He has one child who is two-and-a-half years old. Jowasi has a boutique with a variety of commodities and he has requested this loan to add more merchandise in his boutique. His business is very important to him and has helped provide for his family's needs. He has been working in this business for the period of six years and he is very experienced. With the profits, he hopes to buy more items like rice, nails and cooking oil because they are in demand. 

In the future, he would like to have a large and full shop with in-demand commodities that are important to his customers.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo V. Jr. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan,  Bukidnon. He is 23 years old. Alfredo is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Alfredo owns and operates a service-based business, providing motorela or habal-habal transportation services to local community members. Alfredo has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP, a month for these activities.

In 2010, Alfredo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alfredo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for maintenance. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Alfredo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for maintenance

loans.name: Abibakhan's Group

texts.en:
Abibakhan S., 54, is a treasurer of this group. She is a resident of a small town, Kerben in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She is divorced and has one daughter. The family operates a small retail shop selling groceries. Demand for groceries is always high. In addition, Abibakhan owns a small shop in a nearby village Tuyukjar, where she sells flour. Eleven years ago her friend suggested getting involved in this field. She believes that this loan will allow her to earn enough money tor send her granddaughter to one of the best universities in Russia. Being the main source of income for the family, the retail shop earns 10,000 soms a month. Abibakhan plans to use this loan to purchase convenience goods for sale. Despite the fact that this is her first loan, she is sure that she will be able to repay it successfully. 

These loans can change lives of millions. Mol Bulak Finance has already helped to finance 307 loans. Kyrgyz entrepreneurs operate mainly in retail, cattle breeding, and agriculture. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods for sale

loans.name: Anisie

texts.en:
Anisie is 43 years old. She is a widow with five children between eight and twenty-three years old. All her children go to school. Anisie sells sorghum and she has had this business for twenty-one years. 

She needs this loan to buy more sorghum to sell and she hopes to buy goats which will help her in the future. She says her business has improved her family's living conditions and she has been able afford school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Naseem Muhammad Ishaq's Group

texts.en:
Naseem M. I. (in the photo the lady who is raising her hand is Naseem) is a widow and a mother of three sons. She lives in Lahore, which is one of Pakistan’s historic cities known for its history and culture. She has lived there with her family for over forty years in a two-room brick house in the area known as Mughalpura.

Naseem’s eldest son is 38 years old and sells a local Punjabi food called ladu peethi (made with flour and served with potatoes, carrots and spicy sauces) on a four-wheeled cart. He is basically a street hawker and sells his food by visiting different streets of the city. Her second son also adopted the same profession while her youngest son does embroidery work. He is very good at his work and operates an embroidery shop in the market.

Naseem helps support her family by doing sewing work in her home, which she has done since the death of her husband. She is well-known in her neighborhood for the quality of her work.

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner Asasah for the improvement of her elder son’s business. With the loan he will buy ingredients such as potatoes, flour, spices and carrots in bulk. This will help him make larger quantities of ladu peethi and so make more money. He has been in this business for over ten years, and Naseem is hopeful that a loan will do a lot of good for his business.

Naseem is a regular client of Asasah, and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan periods she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for ladu peethi, a Punjabi food, which her son will sell

loans.name: Floride

texts.en:
Floride is 34 years old. She has separated from her husband but she has two children who are twelve and fourteen years old who both attend school. 

She owns a restaurant and she has been in this business for seven years. She says that this business has achieved results like a house which she built from her profits, and has also enabled her to have some savings. 

Floride has requested this loan to buy more beans and sorghum which she will sell when the prices have risen, in order to gain better returns.  She hopes to have a large stock of food in the future.

loans.use: To buy more food like beans and sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou T. is from the town of Surallah. She is 27 years old. Marilou is married and has three children aged 7, 3 and 1. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She also tills a small parcel of land where she plants and harvests rice crops. 

She joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Marilou is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is now 56 years old and already a widow. At her age she’ll never get tired of caring for her children, although all of them are now raising their own families. As a matter of fact, she’s also caring for the families of her children. She will help them as long as she can, especially financially.

Before, the family had no stable source of income, but when Celia became a member of the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), they started their pig-raising business. She used the loan that she received to start this business. She also started her business of buying and selling mango fruit. She sells it by the kilo. In that way she can help her family because of the extra income. 

Now, she wants to use her third loan through ASHI to buy things that are needed to improve her two businesses. She will buy more inventories of mango fruits and another piglet to raise, along with its different feeds and vitamins.

She hopes that her businesses will become stable enough to provide enough income for her extended family. Now, Celia helps support her grandson, who is living with her.  She wants him to finish his studies so that their standard of living will change.

Celia is hoping that someday they can have enough money for her retirement, so she saves some of the extra income that comes from the businesses that she started. She is also saving for the education of her grandson until he completes college, because she wants to give him a better life.

loans.use: to buy more mango fruits and another piglet to raise, plus pig feed and vitamins

loans.name: Damilya's Group

texts.en:
Damilya J., 46, is a resident of a village, Tup. She is a widow and has two children. In 1998, Damilya bought a cheap young calf, which she raised and sold for a higher price.  She used that money to purchase two other calves. That is how Damilya’s business was started. She has been engaged in cattle reselling for 12 years and has added more cattle to her herd. Unlike some other borrowers, Damilya is educated with a degree in teaching. When the teaching profession was one of the most prestigious ones, Damilya could not wait until she would proudly do her job. Unluckily, nowadays Damilya’s salary does not allow her and her family to live a comfortable life. She has to concurrently work at a local school and look after her cattle. She is lucky to have a son, who helps her, so that she can get some rest from a chaos of every day life. With this loan, Damilya would like to get seven more sheep for a future reselling.  Her dream is to see her daughter graduate from college and find a good job and to arrange a nice wedding ceremony for her son. 

“A good teacher is like a candle - it consumes itself to light the way for others.”  How come the most valued profession has become one of the lesser paid in Kyrgyzstan? The Kyrgyz government is not paying enough attention to an existing problem. According to statistics, teachers’ salaries are so miserable that most of them have to leave to join private entrepreneurship, which leads to a lack of qualified faculty in schools. Schools have to hire unskilled interns and it leads to a fall in standard of education. 
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase seven sheep

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married woman and the mother of two school-age children. She is from Lebanon. She established a tailoring business in her home in 2003. She is specialized in producing handicrafts and embroidery.  She raises her children alone because her husband travels out of the country to work and earn income for his family.  She decided to have her own business to support her husband with the heavy family expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $900 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional merchandise to expand her production and her income. In the future, she hopes to open a formal gadget shop where she can sell her hand made products.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to expand her production and her income

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya S. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter is university student and her youngest daughter attends a high school. Three years ago, she divorced from her previous husband, who is the father of her two daughters. Her current husband is a carpenter and they have been living together since 2009. 

Altantuya and her husband run a furniture making business. Among the products that they produce are picture frames, kitchen furniture, tables and chairs. They purchase their materials and the supplies that are needed for production from Tsaiz market, one of the main raw material markets in the city. Her husband is responsible for the production with help of one assistant. 

She started her business in 2000 and has since gained significant experience. They hire a car, which is costly, to transport their products to the Narantuul market where they sell them. Because of the expense, she would like to purchase a car for their business. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a car in order to transport their products.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida T. is from the village of Canitoan, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Adelaida is single and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, junk foods and instant noodles in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Adelaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Claudine is 44 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of fifteen and twenty-two. Only one of her children attends school. Her husband works as a farmer. Claudine sells green bananas and she has spent thirteen years in this business. 

She has requested this loan to buy more green bananas to sell, and the profit will be used to sustain her family's needs. She hopes to diversify her business to sell foodstuffs in the future.

loans.use: To buy more green bananas to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en:
Mediatrice is 44 years old and married to a businessman. She has eight children who are between three and twenty-two years old. All her children attend school except the youngest. 

Mediatrice owns a shop in which she sells a variety of items. She has been operating this business for the period of two years. She has requested this loan to buy more rice, cassava flour and cooking oil to sell. 

With the profit from this business she will pay tuition fees for one of her children who is a student at the university. She says her business is crucial in allowing her to cover the costs of her household. In the future, she would like to open up a cinema hall.

loans.use: To buy more rice and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Anar

texts.en:
Anar A. is 46 years old and married. She has three grown children. She is a very resourceful person and makes every effort to support her family.  

She started her activities in sales with children’s clothes, but because of a wide number of business rivals, she decided to change the range of products to mobile phones and phone appliances.  With the initial capital of 20,000 KGS, she managed to raise her turnover and now earns about $215 monthly. With the revenue, Anar was able to pay for the education of her children and provide a good dowry for her daughter. 

Anar plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by expanding her range of products. With the revenue from this investment, she plans to open one more selling place at the market.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.  Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to broaden her business by expanding the range of products

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en: Marie Chantal is 34 years old, married, and has three children, two of whom attend school. Her husband works as taxi driver. Marie Chantal sells women's clothes and she has been in this business for five years. She has requested this loan to buy more women's clothes to sell.  She says that with the profit from this business, she will buy a motorbike for transportation, which will help her earn more. Marie Chantal praises her business as it has made a great contribution to her life, allowing her to build a house.  In the future, Marie Chantal would like to ask for a larger loan amount.

loans.use: To buy more women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Meralyn

texts.en:
Meralyn T. is from the town of Surallah. She is 41 years old, married, and has four children.  To make a living, Meralyn raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Meralyn works hard to sustain her children's education. Two of her children are in college and she hopes for them to finish and find decent jobs.

Meralyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meralyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.  Meralyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm needs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm needs

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios C., 56, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She finds comfort in her children. She makes sure that she earns enough for the six children still living with her so that they can have a better life. She has been managing her variety store while operating a rag-making business.

Remedios has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for over a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow a number of times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses. 

To help her continue her business operation, she would like to apply for a 50,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries, and beverages for her variety store. She will also use some of the loan to purchase more raw materials needed for her rag-making business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can leave a successful business as a legacy to her children.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed for rag-making operation and additional stocks for variety store

loans.name: Olimpia

texts.pt:
Olímpia J. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, viúva mãe de uma rapariga de 24 anos de idade já casada. Vive na casa propria e para alem da sua filha responsabiliza se pela sua neta e pelas sua  duas sobrinhas que vivem com ela em sua casa.

Olímpia J. perde o pai muito cedo, inicia com os estudos e faz a 7ª classe, esta fica grávida e consequentemente seu marido perde a vida. Isso causa um conflito familiar devido a herança, ela decide voltar para casa dos pais. Começa a praticar pequenos negócios com o fundo da indemnização do seu falecido esposo, vendendo tomate na esquina perto da sua casa, no período da manhã e no período da tarde ia a escola. Através do pequeno negócia consegue reabilitar a casa da sua mãe e constrói a sua própria casa e uma banca no mesmo quintal. Hoje é proprietária de um estabelecimento comercial onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade tais como (arroz, cebola, batata, amendoim, sapatos e chinelos) adquiridos na Suazilândia gastando uma média de 10.000.00mt em cada viagem e tendo de lucro 7.000.00mt.

Este é o quinto empréstimo de Olímpia na Hluvuku e terceiro com Kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (arroz, cebola, batata, amendoim, sapatos e chinelos) para aumentar a quantidade dos seus produtos. O primeiro de 5.000.00mt foi usado para concluir mínimas partes do estabelecimento, os restantes de (10.000.00mt, 15.000.00mt e 20.000.00mt) para aumentar e manter o volume dos seus produtos.

 Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para construir um botequim para venda de sapatos e chinelos separando com os produtos comestíveis.
texts.en:
Olímpia J. was born in the Namaacha District, in the Maputo Province, South Mozambique. She is a widow and the mother of a 24 year old young lady who is already married. She lives in her own house and besides her daughter she supports her granddaughter and two nieces who live with her. 

Olímpia lost her father very early. She started school and concluded 7th grade. She then became pregnant and lost her husband. Her husband's loss and inheritance caused conflict in the family so she went back to her parents' house. She started a small business with the money received from her husband's passing. She sold tomatoes in a corner close to her house in the mornings and went to school in the afternoon. With her small business she was able to renovate her mother's home and build her own house and a stand in the same lot. Today she owns a store where she sells staples (rice, onions, potatoes, peanuts, shoes and sandals) purchased in Swaziland. She spends on average 10,000 meticais in each trip and has a profit of 7,000 meticais.

This loan, in the amount of 20,000 meticais is her fifth loan with Hluvuku and third with Kiva. She intends to purchase rice, onions, potatoes, peanuts, shoes and sandals to increase her inventory. Her first loan, for 5,000 was used to finish the store and the remaining loans, for 10,000, 15,000 and 20,000 were used to increase and maintain the volume of her inventory. 

She is confident she will pay the loan back ahead of time and request a new loan to build a separate store to sell shoes and sandals away from the groceries

loans.use: Purchase of inventory (rice, onions, potatoes, peanuts, shoes and sandals)

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married and has two children. He works at the local market selling slippers and seeds. Alexander has been in this business for six years. He considers himself to be a successful entrepreneur. First of all, his kiosk is located at a good place in the market. Second, and most importantly, his products are good quality and he gives good customer service. Many people come back to Alexander and become repeat clients.

Alexander would like to borrow 7,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. He hopes to receive additional income and spend it on his family.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Sumaya

texts.en:
Sumaya N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Sumaya has a business of selling vegetables, which she has had for over 10 years. She owns a motor bike.  

To help expand her business, Sumaya has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase vegetables.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sumaya hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Sumaya hopes to own a retail shop.        Sumaya is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to work hard.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase onions, cooking oil and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Tserenbaltav

texts.en: Tserenbaltav H., age 45, lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They have lived together in a house and fence on a small plot of land they own for the past 13 years. Her husband currently works in Oyu Tolgoi, a mining company. Her oldest son is a university student and her youngest attends high school. Tserenbaltav operates a meat trading business at Huchit Shonhor, a meat supply market. She has operated this business for the last 15 years and has since not only gained much experience but also built a stable operation. She usually sells beef out of her stall. Before her husband was employed at his current job, he used to help with her business by purchasing livestock from the countryside and slaughtering them to sell. Now she purchases her meats from wholesale traders. Tserenbaltav is an open-minded, generous and clever woman. She says, “I am planning to buy a car for my family”. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve meats in bulk before the price rises.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve meats

loans.name: Gulbar's Group

texts.en:
Gulbar M., 49, is the leader of this friendly and ambitious group. She’s a resident of a small Southern town: Kadamjai. Since early childhood, Gulbar watched her parents raise cattle. They later realized that they had to pass on the family business to Gulbar. Gulbar’s parents have been breeding cattle for years and distributing their product to many local buyers. The business was started with only 500 soms, and eighteen years ago Gulbar took charge of it. Small investments brought some profit. At the moment she has two dairy cows and two young calves. She keeps herself busy every day. 

Gulbar is married; her husband is an expert in a local firm. He also tries to help Gulbar with business. They thank their lucky stars for succeeding in this business because it helped them to provide a good education for their children. Their oldest son works in the US; their second son makes a living in Turkey. Unfortunately, the youngest son has physical disabilities and stays at home with his parents. 

Eighteen years of cattle breeding generated proceeds to arrange a nice wedding ceremony for their daughter. Now they are working on the construction of their own filling station. Cattle breeding brings only 3000 soms a month, which is not enough for purchasing the required construction materials. The family hopes to get this loan to finish construction of the gas station. Traffic is always busy in their town, so they are sure that the filling station will always be full of customers and that they will be able to repay the loan. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- 

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two tons of cement

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en:
Jovy C. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 39 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Jovy owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she buys and sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, snack food, canned goods & instant noodles. Jovy has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jovy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Alhamdulilai Ii Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Alhamdulilai II” group from Waterloo, a small town in Western Sierra Leone where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) to start a branch. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 2,500,000 SLL to be shared equally among themselves. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Musa T. is the leader of this group. The forty-five-year-old is married to a businesswoman, and they have two children. Musa has been selling groundnuts for twenty years now. With his share of this loan, he will buy bags of groundnuts to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet M. is 16 years old, married, and has one child.  She lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda.  Harriet has a hair salon business, which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase a dryer.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Harriet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Harriet hopes to own a house.        Harriet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by changing her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a dryer

loans.name: Metchico

texts.en:
Metchico T. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Metchico raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Metchico joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Metchico has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Metchico is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm needs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm needs

loans.name: Ilimkan's Group

texts.en:
Ilimkan J., 59, is a resident of a village, Tup.  She is married and has seven children. Six of her older children live separately on their own. Her youngest son is 17 years old and helps out his parents in a long-standing family business. In a rural area, there is not much choice of what kind of business to start; it is either farming or livestock breeding.  Fifteen years ago this family decided to start horned cattle breeding. The main challenge was to take proper care of cattle and sell it for a price that would cover all costs.  Unfortunately, Ilimkan could not afford to give a high-quality education to her older children, which she deeply regrets, because now her children have to live abroad or work hard in order to make a living. She believes in the talents of her youngest son and hopes to do her best to provide a high-quality education for him. Ilimkan earns 2,000 soms every month, but it is not enough for constantly developing her business. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional two sheep for breeding. Ilimkan’s husband is a manager of a household in a local ministry, and she is sure that the proceeds from her business and her husband’s salary will be enough to gradually repay the loan. 

Ilimkan is very thankful for project Kiva for bringing changes in her life and promises to do her best to repay the loan successfully. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly,) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase two sheep

loans.name: Laarni

texts.en:
Laarni S. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 35 and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Laarni owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling cosmetics, lotions, perfumes and umbrellas in the local community. Laarni has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Laarni joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laarni has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Laarni is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en:
Presentacion P. is from the town of Surallah. She is 40 and married with three children aged 25, 23 and 20. To make a living, Presentacion owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Presentacion wishes for her business to grow. She wants to have a stable income.

Presentacion joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Presentacion has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Presentacion is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros C. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 70 and married with nine adult children. To make a living, Milagros runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and instant noodles in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam A. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Mariam has a business selling charcoal which she has had for 5 years.

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Mariam hopes to become a lawyer. Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program which has helped her prospects for the future through her hard work.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Kanygul's Group

texts.en:
Kanygul S., 44, is the treasurer of this group. She is a resident of Kadamjai, a small town in the southern part of Kyrgyzstan. Just like most of the  residents, Kanygul raises cattle. For many years, Kanygul raised cattle just for family purposes but her husband advised her to try starting a business in this sphere. Now, she has two heads of cattle and runs a slow business. Her husband is a cab driver, her oldest son is in Russia to earn a good income, her second son is in the army, her daughters live separately and her youngest son helps to take care of the cattle. Twenty years ago, the business was started from only 2,000 soms and since then, the family has managed to make major repairs to the house and arrange wedding ceremonies for their daughters. Now, Kanygul would like to start a dairy business and she has applied for this loan in order to do so. She hopes to get a loan and to use the proceeds to purchase a car for her son so that he can work as a cab driver. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.name: Hands Together I Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the Hands Together I group from Waterloo, a small town in western Sierra Leone where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) to start a branch. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 2,500,000 SLL to be shared equally among themselves. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Fatmata M. is the leader of this group. The thirty-five-year-old is married to a salaried worker, and the couple has two children. Fatmata has been selling dishes, rubber bowls, palm oil, cotton, etc. for ten years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy dishes, rubbers bowls, palm-oil, cotton, etc. at wholesale
